CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.
Gathered by our Reporters

Beautiful weather.
Four-clap kid gloves only $1.00.
Davis & Davis have two yoke of
working oxen for sale.
The H. R. Co. intend opening a branch
store in Taft's Block in a few days.
Tenders are advertised for another
building lot near the fire brigade.
Active building operations have been
commenced on the new schoolhouse for
the Catholic Church.
The detachment of Police which was
stationed at Touchwood arrived in Prince
Albert on Monday last.
Louis, Lewis, Louis and Louis
and Solitude have been elected trustees
for Prince Albert Catholic School District
No. 6.
The rain of last week was just what
was needed, and is doing a great deal of
good. Farmers are now hopeful of reg-
ular crops.
Chief Factor Bellanger arrived by
the last mail from Winnipeg, and is the
son of the Hon. Lawrence Clarke. He
will start down the river to Cumberland
next week.
Wm. Davis has returned to Prince
Albert.
Judge Webster, Mr. Clarke, Joe Levy,
and others of the crew of the Northwest
and Marquis arrived on Tuesday night
from Edmonton.
The Marquis and Commodore Steals
the Northwest during the season.
The mail arrived on Monday last,
opened at the post office by bringing
Chief Factor Bellanger, of Cumberland,
Mr. Johnston of the Appalachee, and a son
of the Hon. Lawrence Clarke, the execu-
tive architect in charge of the new
Police barracks.
Mr. and Mrs. Montgomery are ex-
pected to arrive here from the east on
the 16th.
We are pleased to learn that they
will pay a visit to Miss Lady
Balfour at the West End reception
held in the Senate Chamber on the 16th.
At a meeting of the Municipal Com-
mittee held on Tuesday last, it was de-
cided to build a hospital, the work to
be commenced as soon as possible.
The Town Council will be assessed
$1,000.
A committee was appointed to con-
sider the question of the different
segments who were on active service
during the late rebellion, asking for com-
pensation for their services.
A meeting of the Prince Albert Lacrosse
Club took place last Friday evening.
Mr. Johnston was elected President.
The accounts were presented by Mr. Speight,
a balance to the credit of the club of $3.50.
D. Northgrace was elected Vice-
President, Mr. Johnston, Secretary.
A. B. Speight, H.
Stafford, and A. Agnew were appointed
members of the committee.
The entrance for was placed at $1.
A meeting of the club will take place this
evening.
Under a sign of $10,000 will hang a nobly
borne sword of $10.
A meeting of the Directors of the
Lodge Agricola No. 12 will take
place on the 1st Tuesday in May (26th),
at the Queen Hotel, at 2 p.m.
The attention of the Directors is directed
to the fact that in the last two years,
ago, it follows, "That each director
be requested to convey their respective
views regarding the question of the
value of the present charter, upon
the mind of each farmer the great benefit
to be derived from supporting such a
charter."
It is further stated that the attention of
the officers who are connected with the
charter of the lodge was directed to the fact
that the officers of the society were put
to a great amount of trouble in getting
standing orders approved by the quarterly
meeting, and that certain matters which
were discussed and which were approved
by the Society and which had been laid
before the members for consideration.
The Secretary or any of the Directors will
be pleased to receive subscriptions for
membership.
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW.
PUBLISHED BY
J. D. MAVETY
PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T.
TUESDAY, MAY 6, 1887.

In no case will you be concerned in any adventure which involves risk or expense.
Advertisements without instructions will not be inserted until further notice.
All letters to be addressed to the Proprietor.

SUNDAY CHURCH SERVICES

St. Albert's Church—Morning Service—9 a.m., Rev. Canon Flett.
St. John's Church—Morning Service—10 a.m., Rev. Canon Flett.
St. Andrew's Church—Morning Service—10 a.m., Rev. Canon Flett.

GENERAL NEWS.

Mr. Macdonald has arrived back from Scotland, and has commenced his Parliamentary duties. While we were sorry that he should have been absent from the House so long, it may be stated that no major matters have come up of special interest to the Northwest. He is, therefore, in a position to do as much for Saskatchewan as if he had not been absent, and we are sure he will make himself heard as "speaking voice," and use every other means in his power to further the interests of his constituents.

THE FISHERY DIFFICULTY

Speaking of the fishery difficulty the Montcalm Star says—

"The cable telegram leads to the conclusion that some progress is being made towards a settlement of the fishery difficulty with the United States. The treaty that Lord Salisbury is now engaged in settling the details on the conditions of the Treaty of Washington minus the pecuniary indemnity should be taken with many grains of allowance. The privilege of fishing in Canadian waters was intended to Canada by that treaty is worth little or nothing to Canadians, so that the only advantage that the Dominion would get under the reported terms would be the return for giving the Americans facilities for obtaining supplies and transhipment of fish. It is evident that the sale of Canadian caught fish into the United States market. This looks to us like a very one sided arrangement, nearly all the advantage being on the side of the United States. Under such an arrangement the speedy exhaustion of the inshore fisheries of Canada would be a matter of certainty. Independently of the extra drain on those fisheries which exporters there would put upon them, the American methods of fishing are very wasteful and it would be found exceedingly difficult to compel United States fishermen to conform to Canadian laws and regulations."

"It is well to see that the eyes of reflecting Americans are being opened to the injury which non-intercourse with Canada would inflict upon the commerce of the country. Secretary Blaine expects that to carry out the threat of Congress would not be quite so pleasant a way of punishing Canadians for the crime of protecting their own property as the present method. Members of Congress seem to think, in fact, that it would bear a very close resemblance to that very unpardonable operation of cutting off your nose to spite your face. He said that the threat of the government will bear repetition. "It is doubtful," he said, "if the interests of San Francisco in maintaining her present coal supply from British Columbia, and adding the important trade with the United States, has been connected with Canada and the vast trade that flows across our northern boundary do not exceed the interests of Massachusetts in the matter of the application of reciprocity as an alternative to commercial non-intercourse."

Referring to Lord Salisbury's proposition the Globe assumes a somewhat whimsical tone, and main points are that the proposal to surrender to the Washington Government of an immensely valuable property belonging to Canada, and the surrender of every main content of the fisheries upheld by the Canadian Government cannot consent to it without stifling themselves and incurring universal condemnation. But the strange feature in that journal is the fact that they now hold that the only way to overcome the difficulty is by "unrestricted reciprocity" while at the same time it objects to our fisheries being thrown open to Americans on similar terms. When Canada received five million dollars from the U.S. for the right to fish in Canadian waters by the treaty of 1818, it was not enough. During the last American war, blighted by the government for not having made a treaty treaty with the U.S., now it advocates unrestricted reciprocity while it opposes the "surrender to the Washington Government of a valuable property and the surrender of every main content of the fisheries upheld by the Canadian people." It is hard to tell what the Globe wants.

EDITORIAL NOTES.

The estimated cost of this year's destruction of salmon is $15,000, in addition to the almost total failure of the season's run expected.

Sir John Lister Kaye is full of big philanthropic schemes for the advancement of the fishery industry. He is engaged in his farming operations in the Northwest but he says he will have a New Year's resolution to make good the loss he has found feasible from actual experiment at Belgrave, on the Canadian Pacific Railway, where he has a farm of 3,000 acres. He found it cost about $300 to start a homestead. A man working on his own account could earn $200 a year. If he is honest, will have $300 more. My idea is that the Government send to us 200 trustworthy farmers, paying them $200 each and give them $200 per year for 40 days per year for keep. I find them hardworking men, and while they are working for themselves they have knowledge of the surrounding lands. At the end of the year, if they conduct themselves properly, they shall be given the company's employment, and they can take up land in the neighborhood of their work. They are hardworking people. In other words Sir John Lister Kaye, in his goodness of heart, is preparing to give away $200,000 to the farmers who fail at an expense of over $50,000 a year to the people of Canada. Sir John Lister Kaye is a good friend to the people of Canada.

D. H. Macdonald, M.P., has arrived in Ottawa from Scotland.

The Dominion railways in the Provinces of Manitoba and the Territories have been granted three million acres during the past year, and when forty miles of railway are completed the same may be certified to by the Government engineer 250,000 acres will be added to the Dominion.

The Scrip Commission will visit points hereafter named in June. We understand this summer, six hundred and two of the certificates issued by Canada were rejected by the Indians, and that they must withdraw from their hands; 267 to legal representatives of deceased Metis, and 335 to Metis who are living in the Northwest eligible to rank as half breeds within the meaning of the act.

FRIDAY, MAY 6, 1887.
TERRITORIAL NEWS

EDMONTON

From the Edmonton April 16th.

Improvements being made in the vicinity of the Methodist Church.

A Roman Catholic Mission is being erected on Stoney Plain.

Poveshell's gang are now that more frequently will be seen thirty-five miles away before in this district.

C. H. Conner, hunter, reported to have met a man who spoke English very well in this district.

F. Prentiss' gang of Indians left this place last week, having been invited by Mr. Conner to go into partnership with G. A. Watson.

BATTLEFORD.

From the Herald of April 16th.

Building operations have begun; several stores already raised.

The price paid by the Indian Department for provisions bought here from Edmonton is a dollar and a half a bushel.

A lodge of the Independent Order of Good Templars was organized in the Presbyterian Church last Friday evening with twenty members. It will be known as Pioneer Lodge, No. 30.

Twenty-one vessels were lost on the coast of British Columbia during the past year, with a total loss to shippers of $60,000.

H. M. S. Compagnie arrived at Edmonton, B. C., on the 25th. The Triumph Flagship and Cormorant are already there.

Mrs. Isaiah Daugherty and Christina McKeay, a neighbour's daughter, of Calais, came over on the 25th. The following passage is worth recording:

A man named Evans, from London, was seen with a $1 on Wallington Street, Edmonton, last week.

A pincushion under pretence of sampling him, relieved him of his pocketbook and money.

Major General Strange is in Ottawa on business with the Government in connection with the Northwest territory.

The Legislative Assembly was prorogued on the 28th.

A special from Ottawa to Victoria, B. C., states that the Chinese restriction bill allows certificates entirely, and that the Chinese must pay a $5 tax each time he enters Canada. This is virtually prohibitory to Chinese legislation.

R. T. G. fell off the steamer Bella near Cape Lago, Vancouver Island, on the 28th, and was drowned.

TOWN COUNCIL

The Council met in the Council Chamber on Monday evening last.

Present—Mayor Macdonald, and Councillors Agnew, Bain, Braden and Stewart.

The minutes of the last meeting were read and adopted.

COMMUNICATIONS

were received from Mr. Clark, with reference to a deputation from the Lorne Agricultural Society; from W. R. Grant, with reference to the closing of the trail northward, and taking some steps to have the trail re-opened; and from Chester Thompson, having now to place about two miles on the street. An account was received from the Northwest Government for $155 for the Ordinance.

BY-LAWS.

Com. Stewart introduced a by-law to establish a police force. Com. Bain moved that a by-law to regulate the licensing of livery stables, hotels, saloons, restaurants, and places of public resort also be by law to license water carriers, dry goods dealers, etc.

DEPUTATION.

At this stage of the proceedings the Council was addressed by Messrs. Preston, Craig and Clark, the deputation from the Lorne Ag. Society, asking a grant in aid of the Society to enable them to erect a grandstand and permanent buildings, so that in future buildings erection next year will be available without delay.

On motion of Com. Braden, the matter was referred to the Finance Committee to report at next meeting.

REPORTS.

Com. Bain reported to the Board of Works, reported recommending that the petition of Chester Thompson be granted.

On motion of Com. Braden and Agnew the report was amended by inserting: "For this season, in the event of no complaints being made against the use of Clark street."

On motion of Com. Stewart and Bain the recommendation of W. R. Grant was referred to the Town Solicitor to report to the Chairman of Public Works and that he may take action upon the advice of the former.

The accounts of the Northwest Government for $12,500, due to the P. A. G. Band were ordered to be paid.

BRAIDWOOD.

Moved by Com. Agnew, seconded by Com. Braden, that the Board of Works be instructed to correspond our members at Ottawa to stand firmly by the Manitoba members on the question of disallowance.

On motion of Coms. Stewart and Braden, the Clerk was instructed to correspond with Mr. H. Macdonald, Esq., the Minister of Public Works to purchase a steam engine to protect the Government buildings in this town.

CARLTON.

The matter of a drainage channel was next considered when the following resolution by Coms. Bain and Agnew was passed: "That Coms. Stewart and Braden be a Committee to see what a main drainage channel of about two acres can be located for, and to report next meeting."

Com. Stewart then moved, seconded by Com. Agnew, that the Clerk instruct the Street Inspector that no more matter be put on Main street until that the drainage and other nuisance be put on King street, south of Fourth street, beginning on the south side of the slope to be dealt with.

NOTICE.

Com. Agnew gave notice that he would introduce a by-law to amend By-Law No. 18.

Moved by Com. Bain, seconded by Com. Stewart, that the captain of the fire department be asked to submit a list of appliances necessary for the Fire Department, and give specifications of the same, and that a committee be appointed to consider the same. Coms. Agnew, Stewart and Braden to meet with the officers of the said Fire Department to consider the same, and report their objection to the by-law, and just as soon as this committee meet to authorize the Chairman of the Board of Works to act according to the same.

The by-law for dividing the town into wards, and by-law to amend By-law No. 9 were read at this time.

The Council then adjourned itself into a Committee of the Whole to consider the By-law to amend By-law No. 9, Coms. Stewart and Bain.

The by-law was read and considered, and on motion the Committee rose and the chairman reported.

The by-law was read a third time, and on motion of Coms. Cranmer and Bain was ordered to be signed, sealed and numbered.

The Council then adjourned to meet Monday next at 7:30 p.m.

MEN AT OTTAWA.

(From the Winnipeg Jap.)

OTTAWA, April 20.

The House had been down to work yet, but the real business of the House will double themselves in a few days. The Government, confident in its strength, not to mention its ability, effects to get its support into the hands, while the Opposition, on the other hand, has only a couple of noses, and having grown up in the old defensive style, is marshalling its forces as for a fierce fight as the halls of Parliament over ever.

The Liberal contingent, when the address the other day was apparently only the customary handshaking which the party periodically indulges in, is preliminary to pounding the eternal stumps off their antagonists; and although that ceremony was a pleasant recreation, the most important political contest commences then the hair will fly.

The Black Rods are likely to be in a fine form, and the diamond will result of the recent elections being still keenly felt by him. He visits the House in his usual jaunty manner, and with his head bowed on his arms, which rest on his desk. Sir Richard looks grim and serious, while Mr. Laurier smart and effeminate as usual, Trow and Landecker wear their ordinary every day dress, but the others don't show any particular anxiety or express they would, just before the elections.

Mills and Edgar, Cook, Wilson, Casey and Jones are all there, and their faces are a noticeable darkened look about them. Yet, they see, they build up hopes larger than life, and expect to receive from the Boilers, and their hopes, notwithstanding their efforts to keep up appearances, are as thin as a leaf like the orange crop of Manicota to form a Minnesota blizzard. The Boiler, as a team, have nothing to do but to wait for their old chiefman. While anxious at the Government's attitude, the Rioters, however, are rather encouraged by the very trip which they through their Province where the Metis leader seems to be unfazed, they seem to believe that the old chiefman will be their professionally new found friends. They fully appreiate the motives of the Grits and feel that they will be able to rely on them, and that they haven't any confidence in them. And so—to the utter disgust of the Blaketites, who are convinced that the Liberal power disappears from view—the Boilers return to the fold, leaving only the gallant Amy to "guard the fort" in protestation of 400,000 votes, the left. Clinton, it is also understood, is still undecided with an inclination to join the Government, which fully counted upon him. There is consequently not an encouraging outlook for the Liberals, and so, hanging under defeat, the members prefer to rent their splendid disappointments on the shoulders of the Boilers, who are for their being kept out in the cold shades. Their debating power, weakened by the spirit of the lyric of the Canadian bard, has been silenced by Jones, the tear-down flag-man from Halifax, who certainly has a good deal to say.

Across the ditch, the chiefman occupies his old seat and looks just as jovial and cheerful as happy chirpy birds in the springtime. His hearty laugh, Sir Charles Tucker, who as yet has not taken any part in the battle, is heard by the Boilers, who are still bright with a kind of curious anticipation of the keen pleasure he will enjoy when the ungodly deluge he will take in carrying the war into Africa. Sir Charles Tucker has always been the belief that he'll be better prepared to carry the war with the enemy than ever before.

Of the western contingent Dartin is still in the same position, and though his voice in the House, the others content themselves with getting their work in the Ministers and the Opposition by constant interjection. This keeps them pretty busy, and as Mr. Scarth toddles along with his pockets bulging out with daily correspondence, he whispers to me confidentially that there isn't such a terrible lot of fun in being a member after all.

The Boilers have been hard at work this week. It takes me a couple of hours each day just acknowledging them, and I guess I won't have much leisure this year. But, ding-dong, if I don't believe I'll have to have two if the latter half of spring is like this. Thus they work hard, and their customers come, and as busy as a nailer keeping up his correspondence, while A. V. and Mr. Royce have been hard at get through with their work with astonishing rapidity. We don't see much of Hon. Wat, who seems to be shielding himself in the Liberal contingent which comes from the far west, between Lake Superior and the Pacific Ocean. What have helped yet, and there are hopes that such an unanimity will be shown in their votes that his duties as Liberal whip will be very light.

G. H. H.
